fields.Notes:
Originally thought this was Mende:

Mende is spoken by as many as 1.5 million people, primarily in the West African nation of Sierra Leone, where it is one of the more widely spoken mother tongues, and parts of Liberia. Mende speakers have used various writing systems over the centuries, including the Arabic and Latin alphabets, and the unique Mende Kikaui, which was developed in the 1850s as a convergence of Arabic script, characters from Liberia‚Äôs Vai writing system, and, some scholars argue, traditional Mende symbols. Today, owed in part to the prevalence of English and French as linguas franca in West Africa, the Latin alphabet is most common. A Mande language of the Niger-Congo linguistic family, Mende is related to several other languages throughout the region, including Dan, Mandingo, and Loma.
fields.Video Description:
Note: the language in this video was originally misclassified as Mende.

This video was recorded by Peace Corps Volunteer Nathaniel in Liberia, where Musu lives. Mandingo, also known as Mandinka, is a language of the Maninka dialect continuum, which comprises a set of closely related mother tongues spoken by about five million people across West Africa, in Guinea and Mali, where they are officially recognized as a single ‚ÄòManinka language‚Äô, as well as in Senegal, Sierra Leone, and Ivory Coast. A Niger-Congo language of the Mande linguistic family, Manya is spoken by ethnically Mand√© communities in Liberia. It is most commonly written with a variety of the Latin alphabet, as well as the N‚Äôko script, which was developed in 1949 for Mande languages.
Demographics: 669,000 in Senegal (2006). Population total all countries: 1,346,000.
YouTube License Statement: This video is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International license. To download a copy, please contact hello@wikitongues.org.
fields.Geneaology: "[ Niger-Congo, Mande, Western, Central-Southwestern, Central, Manding-Jogo, Manding-Vai, Manding-Mokole, Manding, Manding-West ]"
